repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Public Sector Reform Technical
            Assistance Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Sector Reform
            Technical Assistance Loan Project for Argentina were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, project sustainability
            was likely, Bank performance was highly satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also highly satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: technical assistance loans can be
            effective complements of structural adjustment loans in
            lending for reform. Bank interventions can be most effective
            when they capitalize on windows of opportunities that
            provide unique momentum to the implementation of reforms. A
            strong conviction on the part of the highest political
            authorities is required to sustain momentum during the
            implementation of reforms. However, the ultimate test is
            their final acceptance by in-house government personnel and
            the incorporation of technological solutions in day-to-day
            operations. A Government agency has to provide a
            well-defined vision of its future and clear specification of
            how to realize this vision. Consultants can add technical or
            managerial expertise, but they cannot instill the vision.

5079108.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Public Sector Reform Technical
            Assistance Loan Project (PSRTAL)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Sector Reform Technical
            Assistance Loan Project will support:  (a) modernization and
            computerization of the Customs Department; (b)
            administrative reform and modernization of the Central
            Government; (c) establishment of a new framework and
            development of systems for comprehensive public sector
            financial management; (d) reorganization and modernization
            of the Central Bank; and (e) implementation of a program for
            a complete restructuring of the Superintendency of Financial
            Entities (SEF). The project will strengthen the capacity of
            the Ministry of Economy by providing consultant services,
            computer equipment and software, and logistical support to:
            (i) manage economic reforms; (ii) allocate and control
            public resources; and (iii) administer customs by the
            establishment of new administrative procedures and related
            computerized information systems.  It will strengthen the
            Central Government Ministries and the Presidency by
            providing consultant services, computer equipment and
            software to modernize its internal administration by
            developing new uniform procedures and information systems
            for personnel, financial resources, and facilities
            management.  Lastly, it will strengthen the Central Bank
            through the provision of consultant services, computer
            equipment and software to improve its organizational
            structure and administrative procedures, develop key
            information systems and enhance staff capabilities, with
            special emphasis on the SEF.
